snippet.title: Chemo Style, Step 2: Post Your Photos
snippet.description: ... Now that you have registered or signed in, it's time to create a SharePost to show off your Chemo Style photo. Step 1: Choose a Role . Are you a survivor? A sister? Please tell us! Step 2: Come Up with an Inspiring Title. You are most certainly going to inspire a whole bunch of women with your photos. Tell us who's in the photo -- or what you're doing. If you don't want to share your name, choose something fun as a replacement. Step 3: Upload Your Photo. Show us your stuff! Special Thanks to Angela Lemke of InspiredByYou.org for allowing us to use photos of her hats with hair. The model in this photo is Angela herself! ...

snippet.title: Chemo Style: Added Some Photos from Breast Cancer Treatment
snippet.description: ... 2005, Me Pre-Cancer 9/6/2007-- I just posted some pics to my profile, and a few below. Wow, did cancer ever change me looks-wise. There is one photo where you definately can see a drooping in one side of my face. During Chemo: Hair Loss During Chemo: Billiard Ball Hairdo I developed Bells Palsy at one point, a shock and surprise to all my docs. But all is well now. I have a nasty thyroid condition (and I'm sure chemo didn't help it) that causes me weight gain. But y'know, large or small, hair or not..my heart never changed, nor my personality. I'm still Leslie, through and through. Find more inspiring photos, or upload your own, in the Chemo Style section. ...

snippet.title: Mental Health America Conference: Highlights and Photos
snippet.description: ... ... There were so many great subjects for taking photos! Here's Gina. Gina came all the way from Guam to attend the conference. In this photo, she's standing next to the Mental Health Bell. Do you know the story of the bell? I didn't until I heard it at the conference, and the story is truly inspiring. I can't tell the story as well as it's told on the Mental Health America site , so I'm going to quote them: ... ... "During the early days of mental health treatment, asylums often restrained people who had mental illnesses with iron chains and shackles around their ankles and wrists. With better understanding and treatments, this cruel practice eventually stopped. In the early 1950s, Mental Health America issued a call to asylums across the country for their discarded chains and shackles. On April 13, 1956, at the McShane Bell Foundry in Baltimore, ... ...
